text: My dear Mr Bennet, have you heard that Netherfield Park is let at last?
(cont'd) Do you not want to know who has taken it?
What a fine thing for our girls!
My dear Mr Bennet, how can you be so tiresome! You know that he must marry one of them.
- So you must go and visit him at once.
At once!
You have?
How can you tease me, Mr Bennet? Have you no compassion for my poor nerves?
It is a pleasure. I have two others but they are already dancing.
Tell me quickly, my love
That dress becomes her does it not. Though of course my Jane needs little help from couturiers.
It is a pity she is not more handsome.
But Lizzie will never admit she is plain. (to Bingley) Of course it is my Jane Who is considered the beauty of the county.
When she was only fifteen there was a gentleman so much in love with her that I was sure he would make her an offer. However, he did write her some very pretty verses.

...and then he danced the third with Miss Lucas. Poor thing, it is a shame she is not more handsome. There's a spinster in the making and no mistake. The fourth with a Miss King of little standing. And the fifth again with Jane.
Oh, Mr Bennet! The way you carry on, anybody would think the girls looked forward to a grand inheritance.
As you well know, Mr Bennet, when/ you die, which may in fact be very soon
- our girls will be left without a roof over their head nor a penny to their name.
Praise the Lord! We are saved.
Out where? Let me see that.
Unaccountable of him. Dining out, indeed.
Excellent. Now she will have to stay the night. Exactly as I predicted.
People do not die of colds.
It's all going according to plan. He's head-over-heels already, now all he needs is a little encouragement.
Oh don't torment me, Mr Bennet. I mean Mr Bingley, as you well know, and he doesn't mind a bit that she hasn't a penny for he has enough for the two of them.
What an excellent room you have sir. Such expensive furnishings. I hope you intend to stay here, Mr Bingley.

Less varied? Not at all! We dine with four and twenty families of all shapes and sizes. Sir William Lucas for instance is a very agreeable man. A good deal less self-important than some people of half his rank.
What a high and mighty man that Mr Darcy is, quite eaten up with pride.
Mr Collins, we are perfectly able to keep a cook.
Does she have any family?
I have become aware of the facto
Mr Collins, unfortunately it incumbent on me to hint that eldest Miss Bennet is - very soon to be engaged.
But Miss Lizzie next to her in both age and beauty would make anyone an excellent partner. Do not you agree, Mr Collins?
I dare say, I have never met a more pleasant gentleman in all my years. Did you see how he dotes on her! Dear, dear Jane. Always doing what is best for her family.
I have never had such a good time in my life. Mr Bingley you must have such a ball once a month at least.

Don't be impertinent. Our hosts are perfectly happy with our company, are you not, Mr Bingley? I hope I can entice you to Longbourn to sample our hospitality. We would make sure you had 3 or 4 courses at least.
(cont'd) So tell me Mr Bingley. Whom did you like least of all your guests this evening?
(V.O.) We will be having a wedding here at Netherfield in less than three months, if you ask me. Mr Bennet? Mr Bennet!
Oh! Yes. Certainly - Lizzie would be very happy indeed. Everyone. Out. Mr Collins would like a private audience with your sister.
No. Nonsense, Lizzy. I desire you will stay where you are. Everyone else, to the drawing room. Mr Bennet.
Now!
(V.O.) Sshhh.
Oh headstrong, foolish child
- don't worry Mr Collins, we shall have this little hiccup dealt with immediately.
Oh Mr Bennet. We are all in a uproar. You must come and make Lizzie marry Mr Collins, for she vows she will not have him.
(cont'd) Mr Collins has proposed to Lizzie. But Lizzie declares she will not have him, and now the danger is Mr Collins may not have Lizzie.
Tell her that you insist upon them marrying.
You will have this house!
You'll save y6ur sisters from destitution!
Go back now and say you've changed your mind!
Mr Bennet, say something!
Yes, or I shall never see her again!
(to Lizzie) - who will maintain you when your father is dead?
Mr Bennet!

Oh, ungrateful child! I shall never speak to her again! Not that I have much pleasure in talking to anybody. People who suffer as I do from nervous complaints can have no inclination for talking. Nobody can tell what I suffer...
(distant) But it is always so. Those who complain are never pitied. . .
Give my love to my sister. And try not to be a burden, dear.
How fortunate you have arrived, your aunt and uncle are here to deliver Jane from London.
She's in the drawing room.
Oh, if I could but go to Brighton
A little sea-bathing would set me up very nicely.
I cried for two days when Colonel Miliar's regiment went away. I thought I should have broke my heart.
Why did the Forsters let her out of their sight? I always said they were unfit to have charge of her.
You are all ruined. Who will take you now with a fallen sister? Poor Mr. Bennet will now have to fight the perfidious Wickham and then be killed
- and the Mr. Collins' will turn us out before he is cold in his grave
Lydia must know what this will do to my nerves, such flutterings and spasms all over me. . .
(O.S.) We are ruined. Ruined.
Lydia married! And at fifteen too! Ring the bell, Kitty! I must put on my things and tell Lady Lucas! Oh to see her face! And tell the servants they will have a bowl of punch!
And so he should help! He's much richer than us, and he hasn't got any children.
(cont'd) A daughter, married!
When you have five daughters, Lizzie, tell me what else will occupy your thoughts and then perhaps you will understand.
Now where will they live? Purvis Lodge might do. Ashworth is vacant of course, but it's too far off, I couldn't be as to have her ten miles from me
Write to me of ten, my dear!
Oh there is nothing so bad as parting with ones children! One seems so forlorn without them.
Mr. Bingley?

Tomorrow? (recovering) Not that I care about it. Mr. Bingley is nothing to us and I'm sure I never want to see him again. (moves away) No, we shall not mention a word about it. (comes back to Mrs. Hill) Is it quite certain he is coming?
Hm. Why he thinks we should be interested, I have no idea. Come along, girls.
Oh my goodness! Everybody behave naturally.
(cont'd) Whatever you do, do not appear -overbearing.
Mr. Darcy indeed! The very insolence of it. What does he think of coming here?
(to Mary - who is still playing) Stop that racket and sit down! Find yourself some work! Oh Lord. I shall have a seizure, I'm sure I shall.

(cont'd) How very glad we are to see you, Mr. Bingley! There are a great many changes since you went away. Miss Lucas is married and settled. And one of my own daughters too, you will have seen it in the papers though it was not put in as it ought to have been. Very short, nothing about her family.
- but it's very hard to have my Lydia taken away from me. Mr. Wickham has been transferred to Newcastle, where ever that is. Thank heaven he has some friends.
When you have killed all your own birds, Mr. Bingley, I beg you will come here and shoot as many as you please.
- Mr. Bennet will be vastly happy to oblige you, and will save all the best of the covies for you.
You must come again. For when you were in town last winter you promised to take a family dinner with us. I have not forgot you see. At least three courses.
Everybody to the kitchen. Immediately. Except you, Jane, of course. Oh, Mr. Bingley. It is so good to see you again so soon.
Thank the Lord for that. I thought it would never happen.
Exceed their income? He has five thousand a year! I knew she could not be so beautiful for nothing.
All but one, the youngest has been lately married your ladyship. And my eldest was only proposed to yesterday afternoon.
Lizzie!
Lizzie, where have you been? We thought something had happened to you.
(cont'd) Mr. Darcy! What on earth are you doing here?
As you wish to tell me, I doubt I have any choice in the matter.
How can it affect them?
Oh, so that is his design in settling here?
There is no need, for I already have.
You mistake me, my dear. I have a high respect for them; they have been my constant companions these twenty years.
I will give my hearty consent to his marrying whichever of the girls he chooses. Warts and all.
I believe so.
You've decided to take the veil?
If he'd had any compassion for me he would have sprained his ankle in the first set.
Kitty, be so kind as to pass the butter.
As soon as I can manage it.
Good grief, woman. Your matchmaking skills are becoming positively occult.
Well, my dear, if your daughter does die it will be a comfort to know it was all in pursuit of Mr Bingley.
Who's that, my blossom?
I hope, my dear, that you have ordered a good dinner today, because I have reason to expect an addition to our family party.
(gravely) How happy for you, Mr Collins, to possess the talent for flattering with such delicacy.
But...
And what am I to do?
(to Lizzie) SO, your mother insists on you marrying Mr Collins.
Well Lizzie. From this day on 'you must be a stranger to one of your parents.
Your mother will never see you again if you do not marry Mr Collins, and I will never see you again if you do.
Poor Jane. However, a girl likes to be crossed in love now and then. It gives her something to think of, and a sort of distinction among her companions.
Lydia will never be easy till she has exposed herself in some public place or other, and we can never expect her to do it with so little inconvenience as under the present circumstances.
We shall have no peace until she goes.
Colonel Forster is a sensible man and will keep her out of any real mischief, and she is far too poor to be an object of prey to anyone.

I'm sure the officers will find women better worth their while. Let us hope, in fact, that her stay in Brighton will teach her her own insignificance. At any rate she can hardly grow any worse, without authorizing us to lock her up for the rest of her life.
Excuse me.
I am. . . (his voice breaks up - he clears his throat) I am looking for a Mr. Wickham.
For God's sake let me be! (to Lizzie) Lizzie, help me with my boots.
(nods ) Where else could they be so well concealed?
It's been my own doing.
No Lizzie. Let me once in my life feel how much I have been to blame. (wan smile) I am not afraid of being overpowered by the experience. It will pass away soon enough.
As it is addressed to me...
(cont'd) He's found them.
(squinting at the letter) Just wait. I can't make out his script.
Of course I will agree. But how much your uncle has laid on this wretched man already is anybody's guess.
No man in his senses would marry Lydia on so slight a temptation as a hundred a year.
Your uncle is very generous.
Wickham's a fool if he takes her for less than ten thousand pounds.
Before you take any of these houses, Mrs. Bennet, let us be clear. Into one house she will never be welcome.
(nods coldly) I'm glad to hear of it.
That is out of the question.
I am sure they will do well together, their tempers are much alike. They will be cheated assiduously by their servants, and be so generous with the rest, they will always exceed their income.
(tentatively) Could I offer you a cup of tea perhaps, your Ladyship?
Lizzie, what on earth is going on?
Lizzie, are you out of your senses? I thought you hated the man.
He is rich, to be sure, and you will have more fine carriages than Jane. But will that make you happy?
None at all. We all know him to be a proud, unpleasant sort of fellow, but this would be nothing if you really liked him.
Good Lord. I must pay him back.
You do love him, don't you?
I cannot believe that anyone can deserve you, but it seems I am over-ruled. So I heartily give my consent.
(cont'd) I could not have parted with you, my Lizzie, to any one less worthy.
(calls out after her) And if any young men come for Mary or Kitty, send them in, for I am quite at leisure.
Liddy! Kitty - what have I told you about listening at -
Really?
A Mr Bingley, apparently.
Oh, really Kitty.
( ironically) With five thousand a year, would not matter if he had warts and a leer.
Well, if every man in this room does not end the evening in love with you then I am no judge of beauty.
Oh, they are far too easy to judge.
Humourless poppycocks, in my limited experience.
So which of the painted peacocks is our Mr Bingley?
And the person with the quizzical brow?
He looks miserabIe, poor soul.
TeIl me.
The library at Netherfield, I've heard, is one of the finest in the country.
Do you dance Mr Darcy?
Precisely. As it is, I would not dance with him for all of Derbyshire, let alone the miserable half.
Yes! I adore her.
Mama!
(impatiently) And that put paid to it. I wonder who first discovered the power of poetry in driving away love?
Of a fine, stout love it may. But if it is only a vague inclination, I am convinced that one poor sonnet will kill it stone dead.
Dancing. Even if ones partner is barely tolerable.
(completing the list) Handsome, conveniently rich
I agree entirely, only the deepest love will persuade me into matrimony, which is why I will end up an old maid.
Jane, he danced with you most of the night and stared at you for the rest of it. But I give you leave to like him. You've liked many a stupider person.
You're a great deal too apt to like people in general, you know. All the world is good and agreeable in your eyes.
Mr Darcy? I could more easily forgive his vanity had he not wounded mine. But no matter. I doubt we shall ever speak again.
Oh Mother, please! It's ten in the morning.
Mama! The carriage? For Jane? MRS BENNET Certainly not. She'll go on horseback.
Though I don't think, Mama, you can reasonably take credit for making it rain. Let's hope she doesn't catch her death.

"And my kind friends will not hear of me returning home until I am better - but do not be alarmed excepting a sore throat, a fever, and a headache there is nothing wrong with me." I hope you're satisfied, Mother.
Though she might well perish with the shame of having such a mother.
(cont'd) I am going to Netherfield at once.
I have. I'm so sorry. How is my sister?
How is she?
Jane!
Don't worry. I don't know who is more pleased at your being here, Mama or Mr Bingley.
Goodness! You must comprehend a great deal in the idea.
I am no longer surprised at your knowing only six accomplished w6men. I rather wonder now at your knowing any.
I never saw such a woman. She would certainly be a fearsome thing to behold.
And it's a small kind of accomplishment, I suppose.
Our surest way of disappointing him will be to ask nothing about it.
We could always laugh at him.
Are you too proud, Mr Darcy? And would you consider pride a fault or a virtue?
Because we're doing our best to find a fault in you.
Oh dear, I cannot tease you about that. What a shame, for I dearly love to laugh.
Jane, do you think you might feel weIl enough to leave today?
(trying to stop Bingley being bamboozled) Kitty�
Thank you, Mary.
(to Caroline) Thank you, for such stimulating company. It has been most instructive.
Mr Darcy.
(to the coachman) Thomas, can't you drive around them?
His name is Mr Collins. He's the dreaded cousin.
Indeed. Everything, apparently. He may leave us our stays, but even my piano stool belongs to Mr Collins.
He can turn us out of the house as soon as he pleases.
Because the estate is entailed to him and not to us poor females.
Do these pleasing attentions proceed from the impulse of the moment or are they the result of previous study?
Believe me, no one would suspect your manners to be rehearsed.
(gravely) Only a man truly confident of himself would admit that.
Dear oh dear. You must be the shame of the regiment.
What do your superiors do with you?
You already owe me a fortune, Liddy.
No! Please - Mr Wickham
I pity the French.
Will you come to the Netherfield ball then, Mr Wickham?
About a month. Forgive me but are you acquainted with him? With Mr Darcy?
I hope your plans in favour of Meryton will not be affected by your difficult relations with the gentleman.
I must ask you Mr Wickham, what is the manner of your disapproval of Mr Darcy?
How so?
Why did he do that?
Cruel! Cruel! Are you sure?
(exasperated laugh) Oh Jane, do you never think ill of anybody?
If it is not true let Mr Darcy contradict it himself. But until he does, I hope never to encounter him.
On the contrary, he is twice the man Darcy is.
No, no not at all, admiring the general splendour.
Have you seen Mr Wickham?
Detained?
Mr Collins. What a pleasant surprise.
Oh. I didn't think you danced, Mr Collins.
That gentleman barely warrants the name.
You may.
(cont'd) Did I just agree to dance with Mr Darcy?
Which would be most inconvenient since I have sworn to loathe him for all eternity.
I love a Sarabande.
That reply will do for the present. Perhaps by and bye I may observe that private balls are much pleasanter than public ones. But for now we may be silent.
(slightly irritable) No, no - I prefer to be unsociable and taciturn. That makes it all so much more enjoyable, don't you think?
Very mild weather we've been having.
Yes, we of ten walk to Meryton it is a great opportunity to meet new people. In fact when you met us we had just had the pleasure of forming a new acquaintance.
He has been so unlucky as to lose your friendship. And I dare say that is an irreversible event?
To make out your character, Mr Darcy.
Very little.
(cont'd) I hear such different accounts of you as puzzle me exceedingly.
But sir
(surprised) He is?
(cont'd) Please, Mr Collins! He'll consider it an impertinence
Mother. I really think it is time to go.
Wait. I beg you. Mr Collins can have nothing to say to me that anybody need not hear.
Mr Collins
You are too hasty, sir! You forget that I have made no answer.
Sir, I am honoured by your proposal, but regret I must decline it.
(in some desperation) Mr Collins, I am perfectly serious. You could not make happy and I'm convinced I'm the last woman in the world who could make you happy.
(rising, deeply affronted) Mr Collins -
Sir! I am not the sort of female to torment a respectable man. Please understand me - I cannot accept you!
Papa, please - !
I can't marry him!
I can't!
No!
You can/t make me!
Thank you, papa.
What's wrong, Jane?
I don't understand. What would take him from Netherfield? Why would he not know when he was to return?

"Mr Darcy is impatient to see his sister and we are scarcely less eager to meet her again. I really do not think Georgiana Darcy has her equal for beauty, elegance and accomplishments, so much so I must hope to hereafter call her my sister."
Caroline sees that her brother is in love with you and has taken him off to persuade him otherwise.
He loves you, Jane. Do not give up. Go to our aunt and uncle's in London. Let it be known you are there and I am sure he will come to you.
(dryly) I'm sure that will cheer her up, Papa.
Engaged?
To be married?
But he's ridiculous.
Charlotte
All of them?
(V.O.) Dear Charlotte, I am so glad the house, furniture,neighbourhood and roads are all to your taste
(V.O.)- and that Lady Catherine's behaviour is friendly and obliging. As for the favour you ask, it is no favour at all, I would be glad to visit you at your earliest convenience.
( alarmed) What's happened?
Mr Darcy! What are you doing here?
Yes, madam, I had the pleasure of meeting your nephew in Hertfordshire.
Really? Caroline will be disappointed to hear that. (looks at the girl, and whispers to Charlotte) What a miserabIe little thing! They should suit each other perfectly.
A little, ma'am, and very poorly.
No, not at all.
Not one.
We never had a governess.
(can't help smiling at this) Not at all, Lady Catherine.
Yes, ma'am. All.

Yes, my youngest is not sixteen. But I think it would be very hard on younger sisters, not to have their share of amusement because the elder is still unmarried. And to be kept back on such a motive! It would hardly encourage sisterly affection.
(smiles) With three younger sisters grown up, your Ladyship can hardly expect me to own to it.
No, I beg you
Lady Catherine, I am not afflicted with false modesty and when I say I play poorly ...
You mean to frighten me, Mr Darcy, by coming in all your state to hear me, but I won't be alarmed even though your sister does play so well.
You really care to know?

(cont'd) Prepare yourself for something very dreadful. (stops playing) The first time I saw him, at the Assembly, he danced with nobody at all - even though gentlemen were scarce and there was more than one young lady who was sitting down without a partner.
(smiles sweetly) True, aMRS.nd nobody can be introduced in a ballroom.
Perhaps you should take your aunt's advice and practice.
(astonished) Mr Darcy!
(cont'd) Please, do be seated. (pause) I'm afraid Mr and Mrs Collins are gone on business to the village.
I believe so - and she could not have bestowed her kindness on a more grateful subject.
He is indeed lucky to have found one of the few sensible women who would have accepted him.
I have no idea.
How long do you plan to stay in Kent, Colonel?
Everyone appears to be at his disposal. I wonder he does not marry and secure a lasting convenience of that kind.
Really?
(faltering slightly) Who was the man?
Did Mr Darcy give you his reasons for this interference?
I don't understand...
(voice shaking) Sir, I appreciate the struggle you have been through, and I am very sorry to have caused you pain. Believe me, it was unconsciously done.
Yes, sir.
No!
(pause) I'm sure that the feelings which, as you've told me, have hindered your regard, will help you in overcoming it.

(trembling with emotion) I might as well enquire why, with so evident a design of insulting me, you chose to tell me that you liked me against your better judgement. If I was uncivil, that was some excuse -
But I have other reasons, you know I have!
Do you think that anything might tempt me to accept the man who has ruined, perhaps for ever, the happiness of a most beloved sister?

(cont'd) Do you deny it, Mr Darcy? That you've separated a young couple who loved each other, exposing your friend to the censure of the world for caprice, and my sister to its derision for disappointed hopes, and involving them both in misery of the acutest kind?
(blurts out) How could you do it?
That's because she's shy!
Because you suggested it!
My sister hardly shows her true feelings to me! (pause, takes a breath) I suppose you suspect that his fortune had same bearing on the matter?
What was?
Did my sister give that impression?
Our want of connection? Mr Bingley didn't vex himself about that!
How, sir?
(icy) And what about Mr Wickham?
What excuse can you give for your behaviour to him?
He told me of his misfortunes.
You have ruined his chances, and yet treat him with sarcasm?
My pride?

And those are the words of a gentleman? From the first moment I met you, your arrogance and conceit, your selfish disdain of the feelings of others, made me realize that you were the last man in the world I could ever be prevailed upon to marry.
I was caught off-guard.
No! Charlotte, I shall be quite all right. Please, give Lady de Bourgh my apologies. You must not keep her waiting.
I hardly know.
How is Jane?
Oh Jane?
Kitty, what's happened?
Mother! Are you all mad?
Please Papa, don't let her go!

(with great emotion) If you, dear father, will not take the trouble to check her, she will be fixed forever as the silliest and most determined flirt who ever made her family ridiculous. And Kitty will follow, as she always does.
(really angry now) Peace! Is that all you care about?
Father, it's dangerous!
No wonder our family is treated with contempt.
Believe me, men are either eaten up with arrogance or stupidity. And if they are amiable they're so easily led that they have no minds of their own whatsoever.
I saw Mr. Darcy when I was in Rosings.
I would rather stay here.
(very uncomfortable) I must own that I'm tired of great houses. All those carpets and curtains...
- if Pemberley is anything like Mr. Darcy, I am sure I will not be able to bear it.
I hear that Pemberley is not far from here.
You see something of the owner, do you, in town?
Only a little.
Yes, yes I daresay he is.
Are they at home?
I thought you were in London.
(cont'd) I'm visiting Derbyshire with my uncle and aunt.
Very pleasant. Tomorrow we go to Matlock.
Yes. At the Rose and Crown.
(cont'd) I'm so sorry to intrude. They said the house was open for visitors. I had no idea...
Oh no! I'm very fond of walking.
(stares) To dine with him?
His sister?
Oh, thank you.
(cont'd) What a beautiful pianoforte.
Your unfortunate brother once had to put up with my playing for a whole evening.
Then he has perjured himself most profoundly.
Quite well is not verywell. I am satisfied.
Yes, very.
That is a kindness he will never forget, Sir.
Only when forced.
It is so beautiful up here. I will be sorry to leave.
(cont'd) You have been a most gracious host. I'm sure my aunt and uncle will talk of nothing else for days.
It does you credit, sir.
(delighted) It's from Jane.
No, I'm perfectly well. Truly.
(cont'd) It is the most dreadful news. Lydia has run away - with Mr. Wickham. They are gone together from Brighton to Lord knows where. She has no money, no connections, I fear she is lost forever.
No, it is my fault. I might have prevented all of it merely by being open with my sisters.
Father has gone to London. But I know very well that nothing can be done. We have not the smallest hope.
Sir, I think it is too late.
He hasn't found him yet, Mama.
Don't judge her, Kitty. It is, after all, hardest on her.
The difficulty is not knowing anything.
Oh father, I'm so sorry.
You mustn't be too severe on yourself.
Give it to me. (she reads)
They will be, if father will settle a hundred pounds a year on her. That is Wickham's condition.
You will agree to this, father?
Ah, I see.
Do you think it a large sum?
We should thank our uncle, Mama.
Is that all you think about?
(in desperation) You don't know what he's like.
(furious) Lydia!
I don't want to hear
Can't you understand why?
(stares) Mr. Darcy?
Mr. Darcy was at your wedding?
Mr. Darcy?
(nods ) I met Mr. Darcy's sister.
Very much. (looks at him) We found a great deal to talk about.
(cont'd) (low voice) Why was Mr. Darcy there?
Please, Lydia! Please, please tell me.
(stares) For what?
Everything?
Why? Why did he do it?
Do you hope to stay long in the country, Mr. Bingley?
Are you well, Mr. Darcy?
Well, I hope the weather stays fine, for your sport.
(a pause) So soon?
(laughing) Oh yes?
I think you are in great danger of making him as much in love with you as ever.
Don't say that.
Oh Jane, I have been so blind.
How did he account for it?
Unfathomable.
Bravo! That is the most unforgiving speech you've ever made.
Perhaps Mr. Collins has a cousin.It's no less than I deserve.
Lady Catherine!
Indeed you are mistaken. I cannot account for this honour at all.
If you believed it impossible, I wonder you took the trouble of coming so far.
(coolly) Your coming here will be rather a confirmation, surely, if indeed such a report exists.
I have never heard of it.
I do not pretend to possess equal frankness with your ladyship. You may ask the questions, which I may not choose to answer.
Your Ladyship declared it to be impossible.
Only this - if that is the case you can have no reason to suppose he will make an offer to me.
I am not.
I will not. And I certainly never shall. You have insulted me in every possible way and can now have nothing further to say. I must ask you to leave immediately. Good night.
Just a small misunderstanding.
For once in your life. Just leave me alone.
I couldn't sleep
After what you have done for Lydia and for all I know, for Jane also, it is I who should be making amends.
Well, then.
(cont'd) You're cold.
Mr. Darcy has come to speak with Papa.
No, Papa.
(uncomfortable) Have you no other objection than your belief in my indifference?
(tears in her eyes) I do like him! (with passion) I love him! He's not proud. I was wrong, entirely wrong about him. You don't know him, Papa.. if I told you what he's really like. What he's done.

(shakes her head) No, you mustn't tell anyone! He wouldn't want it. (pause) We misjudged him, me more than anyone. In every way, not just in this matter. I've been nonsensical. He's been a fool! About Jane, about so many things. Then so have I... (breathless pause) You see, he and I are so similar.. .we're both so stubborn. . . (shaky laugh) Oh Papa. . .
(nods) Very much.
Oh thank you!
Very well, only I wish you would not call me "my dear".
It's what my father always calls my mother when he's cross about something.
Let me think. Lizzie for everyday. My Pearl for Sundays and Goddess Divine - but only on special occasions.
(suddenly serious) Oh no. You can only call me Mrs. Darcy when you are entirely and perfectly and incandescently happy.
Never mind that, there's a Mr Bingley arrived from the North
- and five thousand a year!
And he's single!
Are you listening? You never listen.
He's sure to be handsome.
So will he come to the ball tomorrow?
No, I need it! It makes Kitty look like a pudding.
